Package com.hoddmimes.distributor

Class DistributorConnectionConfiguration

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.hoddmimes.distributor.DistributorConnectionConfiguration
  • public class DistributorConnectionConfiguration
extends java.lang.Object
    A DistributorConnectionConfiguration instance wraps the parameters defining the characteristics and behavior for a Distributor Connection. The DistributorConnectionConfiguration object is passed as parameter to the method creating a connection instance i.e. Distributor.createConnection. The attributes in the DistributorConnectionConfigurationobject should be set before the connection is created i.e. they are not dynamic.

        public DistributorConnectionConfiguration​(java.lang.String pMcaAddress,
                                          int pMcaSourcePort)
        Constructor for creating a DistributorConnectionConfiguration instance
        Parameters:
        pMcaAddress - UDP (class D) address used when sending / receiving data
        pMcaSourcePort - UPD port on which data will be read and sent

        Returns:
        true if being a CMA otherwise false.

      • setCmaConnection

        public void setCmaConnection​(boolean pFlag)
        Set that connection should be a Configuration Multicast Connection. By default it is false, let it be that way, trust me!.
        Parameters:
        pFlag -

      • setStatisticFilename

        public void setStatisticFilename​(java.lang.String pFilename)
        Sets the name of the file to which statistical information for the connection periodically will be written. By default the name is "null" the name is implicated generated based on the application name given and a time stamp when the the file is created.
        Parameters:
        pFilename - statistical log file

      • setMcaNetworkInterface

        public void setMcaNetworkInterface​(java.lang.String pInterface)
        Sets the interface that will be used when sending / receiving data. By default INET_ANY is used. I.e. information may be received and sent on any interface.
        Parameters:
        pInterface - interface symbolic name.

      • getSenderIdPort

        public int getSenderIdPort()
        Returns the sender port id that uniquely identifies the connection within the host.
        Returns:
        int, sender id port

      • setSenderIdPort

        public void setSenderIdPort​(int pValue)
        Sets a connection sender port. Multiple applications can start the same connection i.e. use same UDP address / UDP port in order for receivers to make a distinction between two different application using the same connection on the same host a connection will use an additional "sender-id-port". Normally the distributor allocates this "sender-id-port" implicit when the connection (by binding a server tcp/ip). But for some reason it is possible to set this manually via this routine.
        Parameters:
        pValue - sender-id-port

      • getMcaPort

        public int getMcaPort()
        Returns the UDP port used
        Returns:
        int, UDP port

      • getTTL

        public int getTTL()
        Returns the TTL being used when sending data
        Returns:
        int, time-to-live value

        Parameters:

      • getReadThreads

        public int getReadThreads()
        Returns the number of reader threads going to be started
        Returns:
        int, read threads.

      • setReadThreads

        public void setReadThreads​(int pValue)
        Sets the number of reader threads reading data. By the default one thread is started. Possibly having additional threads could result in better overlapp. Not convinced that multiple reader threads will make a difference.
        Parameters:
        pValue - number of reader threads to start.

      • getHearbeatInterval

        public long getHearbeatInterval()
        Returns the heartbeat interval being used.
        Returns:
        long, heartbeat interval in milliseconds

      • setHearbeatInterval

        public void setHearbeatInterval​(long pValue)
        Sets the heartbeat interval. In case no data is being sent on the connection a heartbeat message with the latest published sequence number will be sent inorder of receivers to discover if last message transmitted was lost.
        Parameters:
        pValue - heartbeat interval in milliseconds

      • getHearbeatMaxLost

        public long getHearbeatMaxLost()
        returns the maximum number of consequtive heartbeats that could be "lost" from a remote connection before the remote connection is considered to be "dead"
        Returns:
        int, max lost heartbeats.

      • setHearbeatMaxLost

        public void setHearbeatMaxLost​(int pValue)
        Sets max allowed lost heartbeats.
        Parameters:
        pValue - max lost heartbeats

      • getMaxBandwidth

        public double getMaxBandwidth()
        Returns the maximum bandwidth (bytes/sec) that could be sent on the connection
        Returns:
        int, max bandwidth bytes/sec (Mbit/sec)

      • setMaxBandwidth

        public void setMaxBandwidth​(double pMbitPerSec)
        Sets the maximum number of bytes that the connection can push out per second. By the default the bandwidth is set to zero implicating that the bandwidth allowed is infinite. The minimum bandwith will never be less than 0.25 Mbit/sec
        Parameters:
        pMbitPerSec - max bandwidth (bytes/sec). Expressed as Mbit/sec

      • getRetransmissionServerHoldback

        public long getRetransmissionServerHoldback()
        Returns the server retransmision holdback value
        Returns:
        long, server retransmission holdback in milliseconds

      • setRetransmissionServerHoldback

        public void setRetransmissionServerHoldback​(long pValue)
        Sets the server retransmission holdback time (in milliseconds). When a retransmission request is received the missed message will not be re-sent immidetatly in case holdback value is > 0. In case a message is missed it's not unlikely that more an one receiver is missing the message. By hold back the re-publishing of the missed message multiple retransmission requests can be "servered" if they arrive within the holdback interval, this since retransmissions are sent out as an UDP message.
        Parameters:
        pValue -

      • getRetransmissionTimeout

        public long getRetransmissionTimeout()
        Returns the retransmission timeout.
        Returns:
        long, retransmission timeout (in milesonds).

      • setRetransmissionTimeout

        public void setRetransmissionTimeout​(long pMilliseconds)
        Sets the retransmission timeout. Defines the timeout period before an unserved retransmission request will be re-requested.
        Parameters:
        pMilliseconds - retransmission timeout (in milliseconds)

      • getRetransmissionRetries

        public int getRetransmissionRetries()
        Returns maximum number of retransmission retries.
        Returns:
        int, max retries

      • setRetransmissionRetries

        public void setRetransmissionRetries​(int pValue)
        Sets the maximum number of retransmission retries. A missed messages will be rerequest max 'n' times then associated subscribers will be notified about the data flow has been corrupted i.e DistributorTooManyRetransmissionRetriesException is signaled to the subscribers.
        Parameters:
        pValue - max number of retries.

      • getRetransmissionMaxCacheSize

        public int getRetransmissionMaxCacheSize()
        Returns the maximum size of retransmission cache
        Returns:
        int, maximum size in bytes

      • setRetransmissionMaxCacheSize

        public void setRetransmissionMaxCacheSize​(int pValue)
        Sets the maximum size of the retransmission cache. When the upper limit is reached and additional messages are to be added to the cache old messages are removed so that the cahesize does not exceeds the defined threashold value (i.e. FIFO).
        Parameters:
        pValue - max retransmission cache size in bytes.

      • getRetransmissionCacheLifeTime

        public int getRetransmissionCacheLifeTime()
        Returns the time an message will be kept in the retransmission cache before being removed from the cache
        Returns:
        int, time in seconds.

      • setRetransmissionCacheLifeTime

        public void setRetransmissionCacheLifeTime​(int pValue)
        Sets the time an message will be kept in the retransmission cache before being removed from the cache. A value of zero results in an infinite cache life time.

        This mechanism works in conjuction with the cache-max-size. An element is removed either when it the life time expires or when there is a need for new messages i.e. FIFO.

        Parameters:
        pValue - time in seconds.

      • setRetransmissionCacheCleanInterval

        public void setRetransmissionCacheCleanInterval​(long pInterval)
        Sets how frequently the retransmission cache will be sweeped and purged.
        Parameters:
        pInterval - in milliseconds.

      • getRetransmissionCacheCleanInterval

        public long getRetransmissionCacheCleanInterval()
        Returns how frequently the retransmission cache will be sweeped and purged.
        Returns:
        long, cleaning interval

      • getNaggingWindowInterval

        public int getNaggingWindowInterval()
        Returns the nagging interval check
        Returns:
        int, interval in seconds

      • setNaggingWindowInterval

        public void setNaggingWindowInterval​(int pValue)
        Sets the nagging check interval. Each connection will monitor themself to see if they misbehave i.e. if they generate too many retransmission request. The connection will every "interval" examine if a retransmission request has been sent since the previous check. If 'n' (tick-limit) consequtive intervals with retransmission requests has been detected the connection will consider it self to be nagging an generate an error to subscribers and publishers. The connection is the considered as corrupted and should be closed.
        Parameters:
        pValue - check interval in seconds

      • getNaggingCheckInterval

        public int getNaggingCheckInterval()
        Returns nagging tick limit.
        Returns:
        int, max consequetive ticks

      • setNaggingCheckInterval

        public void setNaggingCheckInterval​(int pValue)
        Sets the max consequetive naggiging ticks intervals. Each connection will monitor themself to see if they misbehave i.e. if they generate too many retransmission request. The connection will every "windows interval" examine if a retransmission request has been sent since the previous check. If there has been retransmissions during every window for the whole check interval the connection will consider it self to be nagging an generate an error to subscribers and publishers. The connection is the considered as corrupted and should be closed.
        Parameters:
        pValue - max consequetive ticks

      • setNaggingMaxRetransmissions

        public void setNaggingMaxRetransmissions​(int pValue)
        Sets the number of retransmissions that must have been issued during the nagging check interval in order to consider the connection to be "nagging".
        Parameters:
        pValue - retransmission count

      • getNaggingMaxRetransmissions

        public int getNaggingMaxRetransmissions()
        Returns the number of retransmissions that must have been issued during the nagging check interval in order to consider the connection to be "nagging".
        Returns:
        int retransmission count

      • getMaxReceiveQueueElements

        public int getMaxReceiveQueueElements()
        Returns upper limit of elements in the delivery queue.
        Returns:
        int, max undelivered updates to an application

      • setMaxReceiveQueueElements

        public void setMaxReceiveQueueElements​(int pValue)
        Sets the max number of element that could exists in the delivery queue to the application before an error is signaled to the application and the connection becommes in an error state. By the deafult no limit is set, this implies that the queue can grow beyond any limit and the application runs out of memory. This will happen if updates are delivered to the application in a higher rate than the application can process them.
        Parameters:
        pValue - max elements in the delivery queue

      • setConfigurationInterval

        Sets how frequently the connection should announce its presents
        Parameters:
        pValue - interval in milliseconds

      • getStatisticsLogInterval

        Returns:

      • setStatisticsLogInterval

        public void setStatisticsLogInterval​(long pInterval)
        Sets the logging interval with which statistical information will be written to the statistical log file. By the default the interval is zero implicating that no logging will take place.
        Parameters:
        pInterval - logging interval in milliseconds

      • setFakeXtaErrorRate

        public void setFakeXtaErrorRate​(int pValue)
        Sets how frequently transmission error should be faked. The purpose with this attribute is to be able to simulate transmission errors and test the recovery mechanism. The value given specifies the error rate in milli precentage. For example "10" will in average result in 10 dropped messages for every 1000 sent messages.
        Parameters:
        pValue - error rate in milli presentage

      • getFakeXtaErrorRate

        public int getFakeXtaErrorRate()
        Returns the XTA simulated error rate
        Returns:
        simulated error rate in milli precentage.

      • setFakeRcvErrorRate

        public void setFakeRcvErrorRate​(int pValue)
        Sets how frequently receiver error should be faked. The purpose with this attribute is to be able to simulate transmission errors and test the recovery mechanism. The value given specifies the error rate in milli precentage. For example "10" will in average result in 10 dropped messages for every 1000 sent messages.
        Parameters:
        pValue - error rate in milli presentage

      • getFakeRcvErrorRate

        public int getFakeRcvErrorRate()
        Returns the simulated receive error rate
        Returns:
        simulated error rate in milli precentage.

      • setSenderIdPortOffset

        public void setSenderIdPortOffset​(int pValue)
        Sets the port offset where the distributor will try to allocate sender ports. The port offset should be somewhere between 1024-65000. Normally you should use the default value 61234.
        Parameters:
        pValue - sender port offset

      • getSenderIdPortOffset

        public int getSenderIdPortOffset()
        Returns the the sender id port offset
        Returns:
        int, port offset

      • setSendHoldbackDelay

        public void setSendHoldbackDelay​(long pHoldbackDelay)
        Sets the sender holdback time. The distributor is normally trying to publish an update as fast a possibly. This results in few updates and many physical I/O In case of relatively high update rates a holdback will increase more updates going into the packages and the overall number of I/O being reduced, resulting in an better throughput. The general approach is that a package is sent when being filled or holdback timer expires.
        Parameters:
        pHoldbackDelay - holdback time in milliseconds

      • getSendHoldbackDelay

        public long getSendHoldbackDelay()
        Returns the sender holdback time.
        Returns:
        long, sender holdback time in milliseconds.

      • setSendHoldbackThreshold

        public void setSendHoldbackThreshold​(int pHoldbackThreshold)
        Sets the holdback threashold value. The holdback value sets the rate when the holdback wil kick in. In case the update rate is lower than the holdback threashold value the distributor will publish update as soon as possible. If the rate is higher the holdback will be applied.
        Parameters:
        pHoldbackThreshold - holdback treashold back

      • getSendHoldbackThreshold

        public int getSendHoldbackThreshold()
        Returns the holdback treashold value
        Returns:
        int, holdback treashold value

      • setSegmentSize

        public void setSegmentSize​(int pValue)
        Sets the packets size with what the distributor will publish messages. The segment size must be less than 64 Kb (limit of UDP messages).
        Parameters:
        pValue - distributor segment size.

      • getSegmentSize

        public int getSegmentSize()
        Returns the distributor segment/package size.
        Returns:
        int, segment size in bytes.

      • setSmallSegmentSize

        public void setSmallSegmentSize​(int pValue)
        Sets the segment size used when sending distributor controll messages like heartbeats, configuration messages etc. By default the small segment size is set to 512 and there should be no reason to change this value.
        Parameters:
        pValue - small segment size in bytes.

      • getSmallSegmentSize

        public int getSmallSegmentSize()
        Returns the size of small segments.
        Returns:
        int, smal segment size in bytes.
